questions.question: Which of the following is an example of passive immunotherapy?
questions.answer: Rituximab (monoclonal antibody)

questions.question: What is a common use of active immunotherapy in cancer treatment?
options: To directly kill cancer cells using monoclonal antibodies
To stimulate the immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells
To provide immediate immune support in cancer patients
To supply antibodies directly to the bloodstream
To neutralize toxins produced by cancer cells
questions.answer: To stimulate the immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of passive immunotherapy?
options: It requires the patient’s immune system to be activated
It can cause allergic reactions or immune responses against the antibodies
It stimulates the production of immune cells
It works best in patients with strong immune systems
questions.answer: It can cause allergic reactions or immune responses against the antibodies

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of active immunotherapy?
options: Stimulation of the body’s immune system
Used in cancer and infectious disease treatments
questions.answer: Immediate immune protection
questions.key: Not a Characteristic of Active Immunotherapy

questions.question: Which of the following types of therapy is based on providing temporary immunity by administering antibodies from another source?
questions.answer: Passive immunotherapy

questions.question: What is the primary goal of immunosuppression therapy?
options: To prevent rejection of transplanted organs
questions.answer: To prevent rejection of transplanted organs

questions.question: Which of the following is an immunosuppressive drug?
questions.answer: Cyclosporine

questions.question: Why are immunosuppressive drugs necessary for organ transplantation?
options: To increase blood flow to the new organ
To prevent the recipient's immune system from attacking the new organ
questions.answer: To prevent the recipient's immune system from attacking the new organ

questions.question: What is the primary mechanism of action of corticosteroids as immunosuppressants?
options: Blocking the production of inflammatory cytokines
questions.answer: Blocking the production of inflammatory cytokines

questions.question: Which of the following is a common side effect of long-term immunosuppressant use?
questions.answer: Increased risk of infection

questions.question: What type of therapy is used to treat autoimmune diseases by suppressing the overactive immune system?
questions.answer: Immunosuppression therapy

questions.question: What is the function of immune checkpoint inhibitors?
options: To release the 'brakes' on the immune system to allow it to attack cancer cells
questions.answer: To release the 'brakes' on the immune system to allow it to attack cancer cells

questions.question: Which type of vaccine uses weakened or attenuated pathogens to trigger an immune response?
questions.answer: Live-attenuated vaccine

questions.question: Which type of vaccine uses a piece of genetic material (like mRNA or DNA) to teach the body how to make a protein that triggers an immune response?
questions.answer: mRNA/DNA vaccine

questions.question: Which of the following is a key component of a subunit vaccine?
options: A piece of the pathogen, like a protein
questions.answer: A piece of the pathogen, like a protein

questions.question: How do vaccines provide long-term immunity?
options: By producing memory cells that can recognize the pathogen in the future
By providing a constant supply of antibodies
questions.answer: By producing memory cells that can recognize the pathogen in the future

questions.question: What is herd immunity?
options: Immunity that develops after a person has had an infection
Protection from a disease that occurs when a large percentage of a population is immune
Immunity transferred from mother to child
Immunity against all types of pathogens
questions.answer: Protection from a disease that occurs when a large percentage of a population is immune

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an inactivated vaccine?
questions.answer: Polio (Salk vaccine)

questions.question: What is the function of an adjuvant in a vaccine?
options: To enhance the immune response to the antigen
To make the vaccine last longer
To reduce pain at the injection site
questions.answer: To enhance the immune response to the antigen

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of live-attenuated vaccines?
options: They do not provide long-term immunity
They can sometimes revert to a virulent form
They are not effective for most diseases
questions.answer: They can sometimes revert to a virulent form

questions.question: What is the primary function of a toxoid vaccine?
options: To induce an immune response against a viral protein
To stimulate an immune response against a bacterial toxin
To prevent a virus from replicating
questions.answer: To stimulate an immune response against a bacterial toxin

questions.question: Which type of vaccine is most suitable for immunocompromised individuals?
questions.answer: Inactivated or subunit vaccines

questions.question: What is a major advantage of mRNA vaccines?
options: They are easy to store and transport
They can be produced quickly and in large quantities
They are effective against all types of diseases
They do not require a cold chain
questions.answer: They can be produced quickly and in large quantities

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a toxoid vaccine?
questions.answer: Tetanus

questions.question: How does a conjugate vaccine work?
options: It uses a live, weakened pathogen
It attaches a weak antigen to a strong protein carrier to improve the immune response
It uses a whole, killed pathogen
It uses mRNA to produce a protein antigen
questions.answer: It attaches a weak antigen to a strong protein carrier to improve the immune response

questions.question: What is the primary goal of cancer vaccines?
options: To provide immediate protection against cancer cells
To stimulate the immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells
To replace chemotherapy as a treatment
To prevent all types of cancer
To suppress the immune system to prevent cancer growth
questions.answer: To stimulate the immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells

questions.question: What is the main challenge in developing cancer vaccines?
options: The immune system is not able to recognize cancer cells as foreign
It is too expensive to produce them
They are not effective against any type of cancer
Cancer vaccines do not induce a memory response
questions.answer: The immune system is not able to recognize cancer cells as foreign

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of subunit vaccines?
options: They are safe for immunocompromised individuals
They can cause strong, long-lasting immunity
They contain only a few antigens
questions.answer: They can cause strong, long-lasting immunity
questions.key: Not an Advantage of Subunit Vaccines

questions.question: What is the purpose of therapeutic cancer vaccines?
options: To prevent cancer in healthy individuals
To treat existing cancer by stimulating an anti-tumor immune response
To provide passive immunity against cancer
To prevent the spread of cancer to other parts of the body
questions.answer: To treat existing cancer by stimulating an anti-tumor immune response

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an mRNA vaccine?
questions.answer: Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine
